conversation_id: "688cc20f-0e44-8323-b51b-815738743793" title: "OSHA PPE employer responsibilities" accounts: ["Account1_exports"] models: [] tags: [] message_count: 46

OSHA PPE employer responsibilities

system

2025-08-01T13:33:03.520189Z user

What's the OSHA citing for ppe and employer responsibility

2025-08-01T13:33:06.758726Z assistant

The OSHA standard that governs Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and the employer's responsibility to provide it is primarily found in:

29 CFR 1910.132 General Requirements (PPE)

Key Employer Responsibilities under this standard:

  1. Hazard Assessment

    1910.132(d)(1)
    Employers must assess the workplace to determine if hazards are present (or likely to be) which require PPE.

  2. Selection and Provision of PPE

    1910.132(d)(1)(i)
    If hazards are present, the employer must select appropriate PPE and ensure employees use it.

  3. Provision at No Cost

    1910.132(h)(1)
    "The employer shall provide personal protective equipment at no cost to employees."

  4. Training Requirements

    1910.132(f)(1)
    Employees must be trained on:

    • When PPE is necessary
    • What PPE is necessary
    • How to properly don, doff, adjust, and wear PPE
    • Limitations of the PPE
    • Proper care, maintenance, and disposal

  5. Enforcement & Use

    1910.132(e)
    Employers must ensure PPE is used properly in accordance with training and hazard assessment.

If an Employer Fails to Comply:

Violations of these standards can result in OSHA citations, fines, and increased liability in the case of worker injury or illness.

Would you like me to help draft a notice or compliance reminder for internal use or an HR escalation?

2025-08-01T13:33:15.388482Z assistant

2025-08-01T13:34:11.577756Z user

Nah I mean about the employer has to do the leg work

2025-08-01T13:34:11.694786Z assistant

Ah, got it. You're asking about OSHA's requirement that the employer not the employee is responsible for doing the actual legwork: identifying hazards, selecting PPE, providing it, and ensuring compliance.

Heres the direct citation that supports that:

29 CFR 1910.132(d) Hazard Assessment and Equipment Selection

1910.132(d)(1)

"The employer shall assess the workplace to determine if hazards are present, or are likely to be present, which necessitate the use of personal protective equipment (PPE)."

This is explicit: the burden of assessing and identifying hazards is on the employer, not the worker.

1910.132(d)(1)(i)

"If such hazards are present, or likely to be present, the employer shall:
(i) Select, and have each affected employee use, the types of PPE that will protect the affected employee from the hazards identified in the hazard assessment;"

1910.132(h)(1)

"The employer shall provide personal protective equipment used to comply with this part at no cost to employees."

Summary in Plain English:

  • The employer must:
    Identify and assess all potential hazards.
    Select the proper PPE.
    Provide it for free.
    Train employees on it.
    Enforce its proper use.

  • Employees are responsible for:
    Using PPE as trained.
    Reporting issues.
    Following procedures.

But they are not responsible for figuring out what PPE they need, buying it, or assessing hazards. Thats entirely on the employer.

Let me know if you want that formatted into a document or Slack/email snippet for internal policy pushback or compliance awareness.

2025-08-01T13:37:15.217997Z user

2. NDAs vs. First Amendment

Even if theres a Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) in your employment paperwork, it cannot override federal constitutional rights.

Specifically:

  • 1st Amendment: Freedom of the press
  • Whistleblower Protections: For reporting safety, fraud, ethics, or legal violations
  • Anti-Retaliation Laws: Title VII, Sarbanes-Oxley, OSHA, etc.

Journalists and media outlets are protected from retaliation when reporting on:

  • Workplace safety
  • Ethics violations
